bullets.highlight: Solving the humanitarian challenge is, of course, priority #1.
bullets.text: Much remains to be done globally to respond and recover, from counting the humanitarian costs of the virus, to supporting the victims and families, to finding a vaccine.

purpose: To provide insights on M&A value creation in 2016.
title: Key insights on M&A value creation in 2016

bullets.text: Deal value added (DVA) declined in 2016 to 8.4% vs. 9.8% in 2015; it is still above the long-term average of 6.7%
Target DVA increased slightly to 10.1% vs. 9.5% in 2015 but still shy of the long term average of 10.2%
Acquirer DVA turned negative from 0.3% in 2015 to -1.7% in 2016
The difference between DVA for cash-and stock-financed deals also increased during 2016, ending at 18.3% spread vs. 14.7% in 2015, higher than long-term average of 13.8%

The POP index very slightly increased to 56%, vs. 55% in 2015, still lower than the long term average of 58%. The pop index is the proportion of acquirers with negative share price impact in a given time period, suggesting investors perceive them to have over-paid.

reasoning_strategy: Comparative analysis of percentage changes from previous years and averages.

purpose: To explain how proper incentive design aligns organization with TSR goals.
title: Proper incentive design aligns organization with TSR goals

bullets.text: As the old saying goes ...what gets measured and paid for gets done
Planning will be theoretical and often gamed if plan targets and resulting performance are not
Closely linked to near and long term incentives
Long term incentives should be market based, not internal objectives for improvement that do not clearly back to TSR
Set targets using external benchmarks
Base performance & competition on iTSR and other TSR linked metrics
Timing of incentive structure matters, with three year rolling a useful standard
Longer time horizon prevents short term manipulation and gaming
Multi year assessments work best with long tenured management teams
In mobile organizations, compensation tranches can follow executives who move from one business to another
Important to align incentives with levers managers, based on relevant level in organization
Also need to minimize asymmetries of risk by exposing executives to the same upside and downside risks that investors face- they should have skin in the game

reasoning_strategy: Logical explanation with examples and guidelines.
design_language: Minimalistic with emphasis on green color

purpose: To explain the importance of fraud scoring models in fraud prevention strategies and emphasize the understanding of model performance.
title: Predictive Modeling

bullets.text: Authorizations are assigned a score based on the transactions’ likelihood of being fraud
Certain scoring models are based on consortium data pulling in attributes of both the merchant and like cardholder spend
Industry model scoring can help determine the risk of individual transactions
Mastercard Decision Intelligence considers the risk and reward of transactions
The use of more than one scoring model has shown to augment and enhance existing performance by reducing fraud and limiting customer impact
Once a risk appetite is established, the model performance can be analyzed to determine appropriate score threshold settings
Based on the score, rules can be written to decline activity, approve and queue for manual review, or approve and not queue

reasoning_strategy: Explanation of scoring models and their impact on fraud prevention.

purpose: Address common misconceptions about cloud computing.
title: Let's debunk some common myths around cloud

tables.description: Comparison of myths and realities regarding cloud computing.

cells: Moving apps to cloud increases total cost of ownership.
Apps can be cheaper in the cloud if appropriately remediated, if costs are attributed properly, and if redundant costs are taken out.
You move to the cloud to reduce IT costs.
You may get IT costs to break even, but the value that comes from the speed, agility, innovation, and scalability swamps potential IT cost reductions.
The security I can set up and control in my own data centers is superior to the security on cloud.
Almost all off-premises vulnerabilities result from misconfiguration; security as code is required to enable protection and agility.
Applications suffer latency on public cloud.
Current architectural choices (eg, backhauling) can increase latency off-premises, but different choices yield better results.
Moving to cloud eliminates the need for an infrastructure organization.
While smaller, an effective infrastructure organization is even more important off-premises but requires an agile, product-based model.
The most effective way to transition to cloud is to focus either on applications or on entire data centers.
Banks have different paths to success.
To move to cloud, you must either lift and shift applications as they are today or refactor them entirely.
A range of options exist between lift-and-shift and complete refactoring, with optimized infrastructure as a service (IaaS) and containerization potentially attractive.

purpose: Define and explain various financial terms and costs associated with credit card transactions.
title: Line Item Definitions

bullets.text: Cost of acquiring a new customer through marketing campaigns and purchasing name lists from the credit bureau
The cost of offering promotions in order to push customers to sign up
Some credit cards, usually on the premium side, charge an annual fee in exchange for extra benefits or rewards.
Fees associated with transferring debt from one credit card to another.
Fees charged to customers who withdraw cash from an ATM using a credit card (instead of a debit card traditionally)
Money that has not been repaid in typically 90-180 days is written off by issuer.
The issuer’s cost to try and collect the money that is owed, i.e. through mail reminders, phone calls from the issuer, or in-person debt collectors.

Credit Protection works as a form of insurance for the consumer. Every month, they pay a fee for the program, which allows them to stop making minimum monthly payments in the case of disability or sudden unemployment. Because Jamie was recently fired, but pays for credit protection, he is insured. This also works as a form of income for the issuer. With the monthly payments for the credit protection, total other income increases. However, when Jamie files for credit protection, there is a cost for the issuer involved in that - credit protection claims.
When consumers claim for credit protection, the issuer needs to internalize this cost
If cardholders opt for credit protection, they are required to pay a monthly fee in return for coverage if they are unable to pay in the future.
The interest charged if Jamie decides to keep his balance next month (‘revolves’)
Fee credit card issuers charge to convert abroad and domestic currencies
Cost issuer incurs from fraud-related card activity such as stolen cards or counterfeit transactions.
The fee that an issuer earns on transactions
For transactions that incur balances, issuers pay back merchants on cardholder’s behalf and must pay interest on outstanding balances until cardholders pay back the issuer.
Charges consumers if they fail to make their minimum monthly payments on time, as per the 2009 Card Act.
An accounting adjustment for pre-emptively replenishing the balance sheet to mitigate future forecasted chargeoffs
examples include statement reprints, expedited shipping for lost/stolen card replacement items
This is a cost for the issuer. It is equal to Chargeoffs plus or minus Loan Loss Provision Adjustment, minus Recoveries
The total net income after taxes are considered. This is equal to the Pre-Tax Net Income minus the Income Tax Expense/Credit.
This is revenue for the issuer. It is equal to Finance Charges plus Transfer Pricing Interest Income, minus Interest Expense
This is the overall revenue from balance-related revenues and expenses. It is equal to the Net Interest Income minus the Net Credit Losses.
fees paid to the networks that facilitate credit card transactions

an issuer can choose to authorize consumers to spend over their prescribed credit limits. Alternatively, issuers might choose to let consumers go over their limit if they opt in to an overlimit fee. If Jamie opted in, then the issuer could make him pay the fee for going over his limit
In case Jamie breaks or loses his credit card, ABC will need to reissue the card, thereby incurring costs for the plastic.
lifecycle marketing to keep the consumer engaged. This would include direct mail, targeted advertising and sales channel management.

the potential losses that an issuer might incur due to fraud and associated fees – what if Jamie had not told them about the trip to Cancun? The issuer may assume that someone stole Jamie’s card and will have to pay any fees incurred by the thief
Fees paid to processors of credit card transactions

similarly, sometimes an issuer might get back some of the money that they had previously charged off. For example, if someone was down on their luck and couldn’t pay back their debts at all but then manages to win the lottery
If Jamie redeems cashback from ABC, the issuer will incur a cost for every point

Costs that are not directly related to the Net Credit Losses. This is equal to Acquisition Costs plus Acquisition Incentive Costs plus Variable Servicing Costs plus Reward Costs plus Collection Ops Costs plus Credit Protection Claims plus Portfolio Marketing Costs plus Plastic reissue Costs plus Network Fees plus Processor Fees plus Fraud Losses.
Revenue that is not directly related to the Net Interest Income.
The income issuers generate from lending out secured card’s deposits on interest internally.
includes customer service and payments to the processor companies. Essentially, any servicing cost that will increase if the number of cards issued increases.

reasoning_strategy: Explaining financial terms and costs to clarify financial concepts related to credit card operations.

cells: The card plastic is no longer in the possession of the true customer

The card plastic was intercepted before reaching the true customer
Amateur or organized mail theft; takes advantage of weak Activation requirements

eCommerce, Keyed, Mail Order, Phone Order, Recurring Payments
Ranges from individual hackers to sophisticated, organized rings; often a small transaction is attempted to test the card
Maintenance performed on an account that allows unauthorized use of the card funds
Identity fraud; Can be perpetrated through hacking, phishing, or other; Includes account changes such as address change, card request, addition of authorized users; sometimes familiar fraud
True victim did not apply for or have knowledge of initial card set up
Identify fraud; primarily seen on credit portfolios; sometimes familiar fraud

purpose: Highlight pitfalls and best practices in designing compensation plans.

cells: Use of proxy metrics not well correlated with TSR such as EPS growth, revenue growth
Incorporate TSR/iTSR as metric and target setting device in incentive system
Lack of reward for well thought through investing for long term success
Ensure long term results strongly incorporated into incentives & intelligent investing for the future is encouraged
Executives rewarded for short term performance even if it creates risks to business long term
Use holistic measures such a iTSR balanced with long term horizons
Internal stretch may not equal external expectations
Use TSR benchmarks along with portfolio roles & business potential to set external expectations & performance targets
Employees either coasting or giving up because targets are too low or too high
Set targets based on an appropriate TSR success goals, business roles and potential
Compensation metrics not transparent and/or based on too many variables to be sufficiently understood or managed
Identify minimum number of high priority metrics(e.g. iTSR) that are linked and transparent to executives
Inconsistent application of incentives, frequent expectations, little respect for rules
Design and stick with a system, enforce equally throughout, modify rarely

purpose: To describe the key components of Pan Bank loyalty programs.
title: Pan Bank loyalty program

bullets.text: Most banks are now launching Pan bank loyalty programs, which allows customer to earn points across all banking products including remittances, bill payments, standing instruction etc. Customers usually compare Pan bank points to choose their bank

design_language: Professional and clean with a focus on textual information

tables.description: Table listing factors and descriptions related to Pan Bank loyalty programs.

cells:
Pan bank loyalty programs typically reward a large # products & actions by account holder: 
- Spend on credit, debit, prepaid & travel currency cards
- Reloading of travel currency card through Bank Savings account
- Bill payments
- Credit transactions coming from different bank
- Payment types: Electronic clearance transactions, Standing instructions, Outward remittance through Internet banking/branch etc.
- One time: Registration on IB/MB within 30 days of account opening, Opening Trading account etc.
The # earn rules is also typically high, with multiple rules on each product (for ex. accelerated earn rate on Grocery spend on Credit card)
Banks typically offer various redemption options – Cashback, Vouchers, Points transfer, Points exchange, Travel bookings etc.
The giveback rate for each product can be individually compared between the banks

rows.row_label: Overall loyalty spend per customer base
cells: The total loyalty spend per customer can be compared between banks

purpose: To outline the approach and questions for conducting investor interviews.
title: Investor interviews will aim at teasing out investment theses and recognizing important patterns
reasoning_strategy: Provide a structured plan for conducting interviews and sample questions to guide discussions.

content: Conduct fifteen to twenty anonymous interviews
15-20 buy-side investors
~5 sell-side analysts
Best efforts on 2-3 “past investors” and 2-3 “potential investors”
Interviews are 30 - 45 minutes in duration
Client identifies 20-25 investors and 6-7 analysts (typical acceptance rate is 70%)
Client invites each of the potential participants individually via email or phone- possibly using script provided by BCG
Client will let BCG know when investors/analysts respond “yes” or “no”. BCG will then reach out to “yes” participants to schedule interviews and begin executing interviews
BCG conducts interviews and synthesizes findings to be shared with Client executives
Only IR-experienced Partners conduct interviews
Tailored interview guide that reflects the learnings from each interview and goes deep into the “why”
Tell me about how you invest stylistically?
How did you get from the universe of stocks to this sector, this name
What role does Client play in your portfolio (e.g., alpha, beta)?
Tell me about your thesis: Profit growth, valuation, cashflow; What do they add up to
Tell me about how you think about valuation. How should Client’s valuation evolve in that context?
Tell me about how and where you see Client as strategically advantaged/disadvantaged?
What are the most important 3-5 business agenda items for Client?
How should Client use its cash over the next 1-3 years? M&A, debt retirement, dividends, share repurchase, other?
What 1-2 sentences would you use to describe Client to a colleague who does not follow them?

purpose: Introduce the concept of Lifecycle Management (LCM) and its phases.
title: What is Lifecycle Management (LCM?)

bullets.text: Cardholder lifecycle management (LCM) is the end-to-end, holistic strategy to drive top-of-wallet card status and maximize portfolio profitability over time
Lifecycle management covers the entire customer journey of activating newly acquired accounts to developing and retaining profitable customers in the portfolio

The lifecycle generally includes four key phases - Acquisition, Onboarding/Early Month on Book (EMOB), Usage, and Retention - which are built on a foundation of a strong issuer brand and card value proposition, and must be supported by consistent messaging and data-driven segmentation throughout the phases

bullets.highlight: Each phase of the lifecycle requires different focus
bullets.text: Each phase of the lifecycle requires different focus, approach, and metrics to fulfill the cardholders needs, drive actions, and optimize the engagement to generate the desired business outcomes

reasoning_strategy: Overview of key concepts and structure.
layout: Two-column layout with text emphasis on the right
design_language: Professional and clean with emphasis on key terms

purpose: To present the analysis of customer behavior changes following the launch of a new loyalty program.
title: Department Store Retailer: Measuring Launch of Loyalty Program
supporting_facts: US retailer wanted to analyze changes in their customers’ behavior following the launch of new loyalty program.
Divided loyalty program membership into (i) early adopters, and, (ii) ‘late adopters’, and then by applying proprietary spending data and analytics.

situation.text: US retailer wanted to analyze changes in their customers’ behavior following the launch of new loyalty program

approach.text: Divided loyalty program membership into early and late adopters, assessing spending behavior differences and loyalty evolution.

text: Early enrollers tend to be established loyal customers, spending a higher-than-average SOW in both the pre- and post- enrollment periods.
Among early adopters, the SOW increases post-enrollment, suggesting that the loyalty program may help loyal customers to become even more loyal.
There is a >3x lift in SOW across loyalty program members, regardless of when they join, but it trails off 6-months post-membership.

bullets.text: Choose from Mastercard’s 170 standard segments, such as “Online Audio Subscription Services: Likely to spend 2+ times the average at on audio subscription services”
Or, create a custom segment, such as “Likely to spend heavily with a set of competitors”
Mastercard draws from its transaction database and identifies the aggregate group of cardholders that fit the segment of interest
Mastercard identifies the residential postal codes in which the cardholder group resides
Users have the option to receive a one-time delivery of ranked postal codes per segment selected, or to refresh the listing on a monthly basis
Users also have the option to feed the postal code targeting data into Mastercard’s campaign delivery service

purpose: Compare myths and realities of cloud adoption
title: The myths and realities of cloud adoption

tables.title: Myths vs Realities
tables.description: Comparison between common myths and their realities regarding cloud adoption.

cells: Cloud computing costs more than in-house computing
Properly architected applications can be less expensive off-premises, but that requires managing ROI carefully
To move to cloud, you must either lift and shift applications as they are today or refactor them entirely
A range of options exist between lift and shift and complete refactoring, with optimized IaaS and containerization potentially attractive
The main value of cloud business cases is IT cost reduction
Business value of speed, agility, innovation, and scalability swamps potential IT cost reductions
The security I can set up and control in my own data centers is superior to the security on cloud
Almost all off-premises vulnerabilities result from misconfiguration—security as code is required to enable protection and agility
There is greater latency among applications running on cloud providers’ networks than there is on in-house networks
Current architectural choices (eg, backhauling) can increase latency off-premises, but different choices yield better results
Moving to cloud eliminates the need for an infrastructure organization
An effective infrastructure organization is even more important off-premises but requires an agile, product-based model
The most effective way to transition to cloud is to focus either on applications or on entire data centers
Transitioning high-impact business domains allows for “local critical mass” in achieving agility

purpose: Provide key insights into the sustainability index for the telecom industry
title: BCG Telco Sustainability Index: Key insights

bullets.text: Over the last years the TMT sector in general and the telco and tech industry in particular have increased their sustainability ambitions: net zero targets have been pulled forward from often 2050 to even 2035

The motivation for telco operators is clear: their carbon footprint has exceeded the footprint of the airline industry and will continue to grow with the increased data transportation in fixed and mobile networks if not managed proactively

The historical focus of telco operators has been on scope 1 and scope 2 emissions - now scope 3 is very often focused (i.e. covering the entire supply chain) - two third of all emissions of a telco operator are typically scope 3 emissions
In addition, “scope 4”, i.e. offering digital sustainability services which enable other industry sectors to become more sustainable, are becoming more important
Hence, embracing sustainability is much more of an opportunity for telco operators than a burden - the business potential is enormous!
Even some consumer segments show an increased interest to buy green telco services/products and even paying more for it!

While the business opportunity is obvious, telco operators also need to watch out for liabilities in their balance sheets, i. e. (old) assets that consume a lot of energy - cost of capital will increase and share price will suffer if not managed proactively
In 2020, performance of top scorer improved further, while bottom scorer had no overall improvement
European telcos maintain sustainability index leadership
However, significant improvements can be observed in Europe and in North American as well

purpose: Showcase best practices for customer engagement
title: Fuel Provider Use Case: Best customer engagement

bullets.text: Client was launching several initiatives; a new fuel line, mobile app, and renewed focus on enriching the customer experience.

Client was looking for a partner to promote these initiatives at multiple touchpoints over the year, particularly as it related to engaging customers with a high propensity to purchase premium fuel products.
Developed a one-stop solution for targeting and engaging consumers, developing and executing a series of consumer marketing / engagement campaigns, and measuring their performance.

Leveraged Mastercard transaction data to identify the top FSAs in Canada with the ideal customer profile: those who over-index on premium fuel purchases, have high household income, and are within reach of one of the client’s fuel locations.
Designed and executed a card-linked cashback offer to target the top FSAs.
Hosted a series of Priceless Dinners to engage “the best” customers.
5 campaigns were executed, each testing unique combinations of offer constructs and target segments.
Learnings from each campaign analysis fed into subsequent campaigns and helped the client create a baseline going forward.

reasoning_strategy: Use case demonstration with practical examples.

title: Results at a glance

bullets.text: Data science is one of the hottest and fastest-growing fields in companies around the world. But it remains a highly male-dominated field, with women making up as few as 15% of data science professionals globally. This gender imbalance is a significant threat to sustainable growth and to unbiased, safe AI.
Responses to a BCG global survey of over 9,000 current and former students across 10 countries make it clear that a significant share of the problem lies in the hands of companies themselves.

Despite the hype around AI, data science has an image problem with many students. Almost 50% of women studying for a relevant degree perceive the field as theoretical and low-impact, or as “nerdy” and uncomfortably competitive. Students are simply picking up on an unfortunate reality in the market: Far too many companies still continue to struggle to create real impact with AI, and many companies still fail to instill a culture of collaboration and inclusion in their analytics teams.

Given the many negative perceptions, active and open communication is key. But almost 50% of all female students surveyed feel poorly informed about their data science career options. Companies tend to emphasize the technical side of data science without addressing the practical and cultural issues that women in particular highlight as critical.

Relying on the hype around AI is not enough. Companies must pay attention to how they “live” and present their own data science cultures: celebrating real business impact, not just technical skills; and creating a work culture that is visibly collaborative rather than artificially competitive. And they must bring this transparency directly to students with tangible examples of real-life data science content and ways of working.

supporting_facts: Women make up as few as 15% of data science professionals globally.
Almost 50% of women studying for a relevant degree perceive the field as theoretical and low-impact.
Almost 50% of all female students surveyed feel poorly informed about their data science career options.
reasoning_strategy: Highlighting key statistics and survey responses to support the narrative.
data_points: 15% of data science professionals are women.
Survey of over 9,000 students across 10 countries.
50% of women studying for relevant degrees see the field as theoretical and low-impact.

purpose: To outline strategies for OEMs to gain transparency and influence over the semiconductor supply chain.
title: OEMs and Semiconductor Strategy
reasoning_strategy: Logical sequence of actions over short, mid, and long-term periods.

text_rules.emphasis_rule: Bold headings for each strategy phase.

tables.description: A table outlining short-term, mid-term, and long-term strategies.

cells: A. Build visibility into the semiconductor demand-supply balance over the next eight quarters across key components
B. Plan and execute rapid interventions
C. Build early warning indicators at the semiconductor parts level to prevent additional bottlenecks
Get more control over the supply chain
D. Plan IC technologies, raw materials, and manufacturing processes over a three- to five-year horizon
E. Evaluate potential structural changes in semiconductor supply terms, e.g., a premium for security of supply, extension of consignment
F. Move to sourcing approaches that provide direct control and security over supply, e.g., direction relationships with semiconductor vendors, capacity contracts
G. Identify specific semiconductors with a high potential for differentiation, e.g., in performance, integration, or supply security
H. Define new semiconductor roadmap, including new in-house development
I. Build or acquire new competencies

purpose: Explain the ROGI metric and its implications for business health and reinvestment strategies.
title: ROGI as a Business Diagnostic Tool

bullets.text: ROGI serves as a proxy for current health of business and informs likely reinvestment economics.
Metric & rationale: Return on gross investment (ROGI) serves as a diagnostic proxy for business fundamental health and prospect for investment.
Calculation: EBITDA-taxes-CAPEX ÷ (Net working capital + Gross PPE + Other assets)
Example goals: Positive spread to WACC (8%-10%), Improvement in ROGI over time.

supporting_facts: ROGI is improved if it is below WACC.
Invest if ROGI is above WACC and will generate target or higher iTSR.
Intentionally excludes intangibles.

purpose: Highlight the importance and elements of an authentication strategy in the context of increasing digitization.
title: Due to increasing digitization an authentication strategy is increasingly important to balance cost, customer experience, and sturdiness of technology
reasoning_strategy: Comparison between goals and required elements.

content_zones.right: Required elements of future authentication strategies

tables.description: Comparison of current goals and future elements of authentication strategies
headers: Required elements of future authentication strategies

cells: Mitigate account take-over attacks and revenue losses
Increase usage/preference due to enhanced customer experience and security
Achieve economies of scale through standardization for all channels and interactions
Increase payment volume with reduced false declines
Reduce operational cost with less customer service calls
Actively authenticate users as needed with biometrics or methods

Layered approach: Technology & process
Layering of technology throughout the account lifecycle and across customer touchpoints will be critical to reducing false positive rates, while remaining as passive as possible to the customer

Public information: Use with caution
The future of authentication will consist of a more passive approach using non-public data, minimizing false positives, but also reducing customer interaction to minimize the risk of a negative customer experience

Device: Future of authentication
The mobile device will be leveraged as an important channel for authentication across touchpoints, by providing a host of opportunities to make authentication more effective; opt-in must be managed to facilitate success

purpose: Illustrate common failure modes in cloud implementation
title: Many organizations are experiencing one or more failure modes as part of their cloud journey
reasoning_strategy: List common failure modes and their implications

tables.description: Illustrates failure modes and their implications

cells: Success in implementing a few greenfield applications on public-cloud platform
Determination to use public cloud to drive innovation and scalability in core-tech environment
Companies have moved significant portion of tech environment to public-cloud platform
Companies have left developers to their own devices in configuring cloud services.
Inability to make business case to extend use of cloud into heart of technology environment supporting primary businesses
Inability to build out automation or reference architectures required to use public-cloud platform services in a secure, resilient, and compliant fashion
Did so largely by replacing on-premises with off-premises virtual machines, resulting in few benefits in flexibility and, in many cases, increased operating costs
Replicating absence of standards from on-premises environment in the cloud and creating significant security, resiliency, and compliance risks

purpose: Debunk common myths about cloud computing.
title: Let's debunk some common myths around cloud

tables.title: Myths vs Realities
tables.description: A comparison of myths and realities about cloud.

cells: Moving apps to cloud increases total cost of ownership.
Apps can be cheaper in the cloud if appropriately remediated, if costs are attributed properly, and if redundant costs are taken out.
You move to the cloud to reduce IT costs.
You may get IT costs to break even, but the value that comes from the speed, agility, innovation, and scalability swamps potential IT cost reductions.
The security I can set up and control in my own data centers is superior to the security on cloud.
Almost all off-premises vulnerabilities result from misconfiguration; security as code is required to enable protection and agility.
Applications suffer latency on public cloud.
Current architectural choices (eg, backhauling) can increase latency off-premises, but different choices yield better results.
Moving to cloud eliminates the need for an infrastructure organization.
While smaller, an effective infrastructure organization is even more important off-premises but requires an agile, product-based model.
The most effective way to transition to cloud is to focus either on applications or on entire data centers.
Banks have different paths to success.
To move to cloud, you must either lift and shift applications as they are today or refactor them entirely.
A range of options exist between lift-and-shift and complete refactoring, with optimized infrastructure as a service (IaaS) and containerization potentially attractive.

purpose: To outline fraud rules and their implementation strategies.
title: Fraud Strategy Management

bullets.text: Will decline or refer transaction at the point of sale
Should be utilized on riskiest activity
Recommended that activity qualifying for real-time also be eligible for automated alerts (cardholder outreach)
First transaction will approve, then a block is automatically placed on the account to decline subsequent transactions
Depending on system capability, tiered blocks can be created to only decline certain transaction types and potentially approve low risk activity
Recommended that activity qualifying for approve and block also be eligible for automated alerts (cardholder outreach)
Activity triggers medium concern; fraud analyst to manually review and determine if block and cardholder outreach is warranted
Activity qualifying for approve and queue rules may also be eligible for automated alerts (cardholder outreach), depending on issuer contact strategy

reasoning_strategy: Description of different fraud rule strategies and their applications.

levels.label:
TSR
Total share holder return is a historical and comprehensive value creation metric used for external reporting and proxy

iTSR
Internal value creation metric and analog to TSR is used for planning, scenario development, tradeoff assessment, M&A assessment, incentive compensation- historical & forecast, portfolio roles

EPS, ROS, EBITDA operating margin
Key profit growth, guidance and reporting metrics are important to investors and which will determine key investor segments

ROIC, operating cash and cash flow
Supporting business health metrics(cash on cash returns) is also useful for benchmarking, resource allocation and portfolio signaling(grow, maintain, harvest, divest)

Key value drivers
Operating levers to improve value creation(e.g. customer retention/satisfaction, days sales in inventory; quality measure in rejected parts per million, pricing realization)

section: Key insights on global M&A activity in 2016
purpose: To provide an overview of the decline in global M&A activity compared to 2015.
title: Global M&A activity declined vs 2015

bullets.text: In 2015, global M&A activity ended close to ~$3.8 trillion, falling from 2015 level both in absolute value (-17%) and in number of deal (-5%)
Corporate M&A Activity still represented majority of the total activity at ~90% of overall M&A activity
Value of megadeals (greater than $10 bn) saw a significant decrease (-40%) from 2015 level and also its share of global M&A activity fell from 34% to 25%
All regions fell in absolute terms in 2016, with Americas still the most active region (50% of total activity) followed by EMEA at 26%
Majority deals were financed by cash alone (44%), with equity only as the least preferred (25%)
Premiums paid in 2016 were higher than in 2014 and 2015; 1 week median premiums increased to 32% vs 29% in 2015
Global activity grew in Q4 2016 vs. previous quarter (+46% in terms of value) but fell vs Q4 2015 (-7% of volumes)

reasoning_strategy: Comparison with previous year and analysis of regional activity

bullets.text: Evaluating the current state of the Issuer’s data governance framework
Assessing gaps to determine most appropriate governance framework

content_zones.left: Evaluation of current data governance framework
content_zones.right: Identification of gaps in current framework

text_rules.emphasis_rule: Highlight key terms with a different color

tables.title: Capability Evaluation
tables.description: Evaluation of data governance capabilities

cells: The organization has a good awareness and need for data but this tends to consist of MI only.

Although there is a desire from senior management to establish a 'data culture' within the organization, there is lack of long-term planning and execution needed for implementation between business units and an analytics strategy is nascent.
Limited data accessibility and general governance coupled with disjointed infrastructure is limiting users to derive true benefit from data driving a data-driven culture.
The organization has good tools and people with good skills but is not using them to the best degree to create solutions to drive the organization forward.

The organization needs to balance the MI needs to customer driven segmented approaches with descriptive and predictive analytics and each analytic area needs to create the space to drive the organization forward in this way.
